profiles:
Experience Consultant for IT Strategic Initiatives UC Berkeley November 2011  –  March 2013  (1 year 5 months) Office of the CIO Hired as an internal consultant to provide strategic planning, analysis, and design in support of the Office of the CIO’s strategic initiatives, while acting as a strategic thought partner to the CIO and Director of Strategic Initiatives.  
 
• Created frameworks to capture and communicate complex challenges related to IT strategic goals.  
• Developed presentations for IT strategic change initiatives.  
• Supported the launch of an ongoing IT Leadership Group. 
 
Co-led the IT Governance Project from initiation through analysis, delivering recommendations for next steps. 
 
Proposed and led an extensive, IT strategic analysis, providing a 'line of sight' between campus-wide functional strategy and current IT capabilities – to serve as a foundation for advancing effective IT strategic planning, organizational design, and IT governance. 
 
Wrote and published an extensive report – 'The Role of IT at UC Berkeley' – for executive review, with recommendations for areas of focus, and detailed findings for each major domain: Administration and Finance, Student Affairs, Graduate Division, Faculty Affairs, Academic Engagement, Research, The Library, University Relations, Equity and Inclusion, Campus Shared Services, and Central IT. Manager of Development Support Services UC Berkeley August 2010  –  November 2011  (1 year 4 months) Enterprise Application Services Building on my previous role, while managing a diverse team of project managers, analysts, developers, testers and system support individuals – as well as working directly with the central infrastructure services teams – I significantly expanded the organization’s capabilities in providing software development lifecycle management and system implementation services to campus departments in need of IT support. 
 
Services costed and billed for, as a result of a variety of client engagements, included: 
• Project consulting and management 
• Requirements elicitation and definition  
• Business process analysis 
• User interaction design  
• Software development 
• Automated performance testing 
• Data analysis  
• Integration with campus enterprise systems 
• Vendor systems assessments 
• Infrastructure assessments 
• Security and risk reviews 
• Procurement support 
• Service Level Agreements 
 
Client/project examples: 
• Parking and Transportation: Unified Parking Management System 
• Office of Emergency Planning: Campus WarnMe Notification System 
• University Registrar: Student Schedule Builder 
 
I additionally assumed responsibility for creating, and operationally supporting, a new service model for a 'Development Toolkit' which would enable campus IT professionals to do their jobs more effectively.  
 
The following were met with wide-scale adoption: 
•	Atlassian’s Confluence, Jira (and Greenhopper) project lifecycle management tools 
•	An enterprise-wide SVN code repositories management system 
•	HP’s LoadRunner and Apache JMeter automated testing tools Web Applications Engagement Manager UC Berkeley April 2009  –  August 2010  (1 year 5 months) Enterprise Application Services Hired to lead a new organization whose mission it was to provide software development lifecycle management and system implementation services to campus departments in need of IT support. Provided project consulting, oversight and resource management for variety of IT efforts.  
 
• Built a service model to provide ‘rechargeable’ services for project assessment, project management, business systems analysis, development and implementation, automated testing, and production support. 
• Mentored resources in software development disciplines and methodologies 
 
Client/project examples: 
• Office Student Research: Online Survey System  
• University Health Systems: Student Health Insurance Waiver System 
• Graduate Admissions: Applicant/Online Review System 
 
As a result of my efforts, my role was expanded to that of Manager of Development Services in 2010. Director of Middleware and Integration Stanford University September 2005  –  February 2008  (2 years 6 months) Information Technology Services and Administrative Systems Promoted to Director, the culmination of a progressive increase in responsibility for the middleware and integration space. Responsible for the overall program and product management of the IAM service, enterprise data integration, and real-time messaging solutions for the University. Articulated the strategic direction and managed the overall budget and incremental funding. Created and owned the product roadmap and project proposals. Oversaw the software design, implementation, and ongoing operations of the middleware infrastructure and enterprise applications suite. 
 
• Significantly extended the middleware architecture, business logic/service layer, and web components to expand centralized services to campus distributed business systems and end users.  
• Sponsored and oversaw the replacement of the University’s real-time messaging service – the backbone of the integration architecture, brokering messaging services for over 40+ systems. 
• Served as a spokesperson for Stanford’s IAM and middleware solutions across Higher Education in forums such as EDUCAUSE and Internet2. 
 
As a leader in Higher Education for its real-time identity and access management, group management, and fine-grained authorization services, the Middleware and Integration Services organization at Stanford University served as a role model for its innovations in designing a robust middleware platform which continues to serve as a reference architecture for Higher Education institutions today. 
 
At the end of my 5-year tenure the original vision for the middleware platform was largely implemented, running smoothly, and supported by robust software development documentation and automated metrics. Software Development and Quality Assurance Manager Stanford University October 2003  –  September 2005  (2 years) Technology Infrastructure Services Led a group of software development professionals – architects, developers, systems analysts, QA/testers and user interaction designer – in building a centralized middleware platform for providing identity and access management, group management and fine-grained authorization services in support of campus-wide operations.  
 
• Recognized for transforming the team into ‘an effective development unit with high morale, an extensive testing framework, and a sustainable development process’. 
• Partnered with ThoughtWorks – a leader in enabling Agile development best practices – to lead the first large-scale, enterprise development process using an Agile methodology fueled by test-driven development and continuous integration. 
• Launched and chaired the Registries Working Group to improve communication and prioritize efforts across University partners. 
 
Successfully led multiple, large-scale software development projects. Examples include: 
 
• Migration from the University’s mainframe to J2EE solutions and a Registries based architecture 
• Rewrite of the IdM system and infrastructure services for provisioning rule-based identity data  
• Workgroup Manager and Registry for managing groups for use in online applications and web authentication Integration Testing and QA Specialist Stanford University July 2002  –  October 2003  (1 year 4 months) Technology Infrastructure Services Hired to introduce and establish Quality Assurance and Testing best practices to improve the quality of systems implementation and the effectiveness of software development processes. Became de facto project manager for many critical efforts.  
 
• Recognized for 'literally transforming how the group worked in the course of a year through a tireless dedication and passion for the work'. 
• Achieved significant strides in building quality into all phases of the development lifecycle – requirements, design, implementation, testing, build and deploy processes – resulting in higher quality deployments. 
• Championed the creation of an integrated, end-to-end, test environment for all middleware infrastructure applications, which became invaluable to the University in managing enterprise systems upgrades. 
 
Successfully led or influenced multiple, large-scale software development projects. Examples include: 
 
• Authority Manager for managing individual access and fined-grained authorization for enterprise systems. 
• Netscape LDAP to OpenLDAP enterprise directory migration 
• Organization Manager and Registry for managing University organizational identity and contact data for use in enterprise system integration and the Stanford directory. Lead Software Test Engineer CTB McGraw Hill 1997  –  2002  (5 years) TestMate/Classroom Management Software Development Involved in the software development process from start to finish, coordinating QA analysis/testing efforts for a high-performing software organization. Led and mentored teams responsible for functional, regression, compatibility, performance, UI and documentation testing. 
 
Created system test plans and test strategies for two major product lines. Defined scope, estimates, and schedules. Developed automated test suites to reduce regression test cycles and to provide exponential increase in test coverage.  
 
• Recognized for success in developing automated test suites – asked to present approach and results to the company at large. 
• Initiated major improvements to the defect tracking system and overall tracking process. 
• Led effort in testing complex scoring algorithms to ensure nationally-ranked standardized test scores were accurate. • Supported the launch of an ongoing IT Leadership Group.

Three tracks - workshops, applied learning, and individual development - were combined to enhance the professional and personal development of individuals who play important management and leadership roles within information technology. Program by MOR Associates. Exceptional Performance Award Stanford University 2005 In recognition and appreciation of contributions to Stanford University for exceptional achievement in exceeding service expectations and for demonstrating significant breakthrough results.
